turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about PS Commonwealth (1854).
turn.1: What caused the PS Commonwealth's demise?
turn.2: An attempt to tow "Commonwealth" to safety was made by a local ferry, but an unusually low tide, combined with the weight of "Commonwealth"s freight which was still aboard, had grounded the vessel on a sandbar, and "Commonwealth" caught fire at the bows and was burned to the water's edge.
turn.4: Fortunately, most of "Commonwealth"s passengers had already disembarked and departed by train, but a young medical student named J. Dickson Ripley, a nephew of Connecticut Governor William A. Buckingham, could not be aroused despite repeated poundings on his cabin door and was presumed to have suffocated from smoke inhalation in his sleep.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: In addition to the loss of "Commonwealth", the entire depot at Groton was destroyed, so thoroughly that the Railroad was forced to move its terminus back to its former location of Stonington for a time.
turn.8: Total damage from the fire was estimated at $1,500,000.
turn.9: Why did they under insure the ship?
turn.10: Because of "Commonwealth"s well maintained firefighting facilities, her proprietors had only insured the vessel for $80,000, with replacement value estimated at $600,000.
turn.12: Salvage of "Commonwealth" continued well into 1866, with the steamer's safe, containing about $500 and "many valuable papers", recovered in July.
